thread.title: Heavy Rain Causes Waterlogging in Bhubaneswar and Cuttack | Bhubaneswar News - Times of India
thread.title_full: Heavy Rain Causes Waterlogging in Bhubaneswar and Cuttack | Bhubaneswar News - Times of India

author: Times Of India
title: Heavy Rain Causes Waterlogging in Bhubaneswar and Cuttack | Bhubaneswar News - Times of India
text: Bhubaneswar: A spell of moderate rain in the twin cities of Bhubaneswar and Cuttack on Friday morning caused waterlogging in some low-lying areas, particularly in Cuttack.“I was preparing to drop my children at school and do some marketing before leaving for my office. But the sudden rain disturbed my routine,” said Suresh Kar, an employee of the state secretariat, who stays at Jayadev Vihar here.The IMD report said the city received 3.6 mm of rainfall in the morning. Similarly, Cuttack recorded 10.2 mm of rain in the morning. Manorama Mohanty, head of the regional IMD centre in the city, said only a few places experienced rainfall day due to the confluence of dry, hot, and humid air. We also published the following articles recentlyIMD forecasts above normal rain for state in NovChennai expects above-normal November rainfall as the northeast monsoon becomes active, predicts IMD. A weather system may develop over the Bay of Bengal and move towards Tamil Nadu, intensifying rainfall next week. Chennai recorded 37 cm of rainfall in October. IMD forecasts light to moderate rain, thunderstorms, and high temperatures for the city in the next 48 hours.114860075IMD predicts light rain in Pune during DiwaliThe India Meteorological Department forecasts light rain in Pune on October 30-31, amidst the Diwali festival, which runs from October 29 to November 3. The city's temperature will remain slightly above normal, with occasional misty mornings. An upper air circulation expected soon would increase moisture in the state, resulting in pleasant weather for Diwali.114664846IMD: State to get rain till 1st week of NovA yellow alert has been issued in Goa by the India Meteorological Department due to expected post-monsoon rainfall, thunderstorms, and gusty winds. These conditions, starting from October 30, may affect Halloween celebrations. Showers are anticipated to continue into early November, with varying degrees of rain across different areas, including Panaji and Mormugao experiencing moderate to heavy downpours.114743989
